slots.isEven:
Returns true if 
	integer form of the receiver is even
	, false otherwise.
slots.minMax(low, high): Returns a number between or equal to low and high. If the receiver is equal to or between low and high, the receiver is returned. If the receiver is less than low, low is returned. If the receiver is greater than high, high is returned.
slots.isNan: Returns true if the receiver is not a number. Otherwise returns false.
slots.constants: Object containing number constants e, inf, nan and pi.
slots.factorial: Returns the factorial of the receiver.
slots.|(aNumber): Returns a new number with the bitwise OR of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.isPrint:
Returns true if 
	the receiver is a printing character value, including space
	, false otherwise.
slots.combinations(size): Returns the combinations where the receiver is the number of different objects and size is the number to be arranged.
slots.^(aNumber): Returns the bitwise xor with the receiver (both numbers are converted to longs for the operation).
slots.atan: Returns a number with the arc tangent of the receiver.
slots.max(aNumber): Returns the greater of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.cos: Returns the cosine of the receiver.
slots.-(aNumber): Returns a new number that is the difference of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.toggle: Returns 1 if the receiver is 0. Returns 0 otherwise.
slots.asUppercase: Returns a new Number containing a upper case version of the receiver.
slots.negate: Returns new number that is negated version of the receiver.
slots.isLetter:
Returns true if 
	receiver is a letter character value
	, false otherwise.
slots.<<(aNumber): Shifts the bits of the receiver left by the number of places specified by aNumber.
slots.isHexDigit:
Returns true if 
	the receiver is a hexadecimal character value
	, false otherwise.
slots.asCharacter:
Returns a String containing a single character whose
	value is the value of the first byte of the receiver.
	Returns nil if the number has no valid UCS mapping.
slots.asString(optionalIntegerDigits, optional:
Returns a string representation of the receiver. For example: 
1234.5678 asString(0, 2)
would return: 
1234.57
slots.isLowercase:
Returns true if 
	the receiver is a lowercase character value
	, false otherwise.
slots.acos: Returns a number with the arc cosine of the receiver.
slots.isAlphaNumeric:
Returns true if 
	receiver is an alphanumeric character value
	, false otherwise.
slots.toBase(base): Returns the number in another base. 42 toBase(2) -> "101010"
slots.isOdd:
Returns true if 
	integer form of the receiver is odd
	, false otherwise.
slots.doubleMin: Returns the minimum double precision float value.
slots.sqrt: Returns the square root of the receiver.
slots.asUint32Buffer: Returns a Sequence containing a 4 byte representation of the uint32 value of the receiver.
slots.\/(aNumber): Returns a new number with the value of the receiver divided by aNumber.
slots.+(aNumber): Returns a new number that is the sum of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.bitwiseXor(aNumber): Returns a new number with the bitwise XOR of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.isDigit:
Returns true if 
	receiver is a numeric digit value
	, false otherwise.
slots.isGraph:
Returns true if 
	the receiver is a printing character value except space
	, false otherwise.
slots.isUppercase:
Returns true if 
	the receiver is a uppercase character value
	, false otherwise.
slots.toBaseWholeBytes(base): Returns the number in another base printing out entire bytes. 42 toBaseWholeBytes(2) -> "00101010"
slots.asBinary: Returns the number as binary digits inside a string. 42 asBinary -> "101010"
slots.floatMax: Returns the maximum double precision float value.
slots.between(aNumber1, aNumber2):
Returns true if the receiver's value is between or
	equal to aNumber1 and aNumber2, otherwise returns false.
slots.abs: Returns a number with the absolute value of the receiver.
slots.log:
Returns the logarithm of the receiver.  The base
	is taken as the value of the first argument or the constant e if
	the first argument is omitted.
slots.isControlCharacter:
Returns true if 
	receiver is a control character value
	, false otherwise.
slots.isPunctuation:
Returns true if 
	the receiver is a punctuation character value
	, false otherwise.
slots.exp: Returns e to the power of the receiver.
slots.*(aNumber): Returns a new number that is the product of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.bitwiseAnd(aNumber): Returns a new number with the bitwise AND of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.permutations(size): Returns the permutations where the receiver is the number of different objects and size is the number to be arranged.
slots.unsignedIntMax: Returns the maximum unsigned int value.
slots.log2: Returns the base 2 logarithm of the receiver.
slots.round:
Returns a number with the receiver's value rounded up to
	the nearest integer if its fraction component is >= .5 or rounded up to the nearest integer otherwise.
slots.>>(aNumber): Shifts the bits of the receiver right by the number of places specified by aNumber.
slots.bitwiseComplement:
Returns a new number with the bitwise complement of the
	receiver. (The 0 bits become 1s and the 1 bits become 0s. )
slots.cubed: Returns the cube of the receiver.
slots.unsignedLongMax: Returns the maximum unsigned long value.
slots.asBuffer(optionalNumberOfBytes):
Returns a Buffer containing a the number of bytes specified by
	optionalNumberOfBytes (up to the size of a double on the platform) of the receiver.
	If no optionalNumberOfBytes is specified, it is assumed to be the number of bytes
	in a double on the host platform.
slots.sin: Returns the sine of the receiver.
slots.asin: Returns a number with the arc sine of the receiver.
slots.roundDown:
Returns a number with the receiver's value rounded down to
	the nearest integer if its fraction component is <= .5 or rounded up the the nearest integer otherwise.
slots.log10: Returns the base 10 logarithm of the receiver.
slots.floor:
Returns a number with the receiver's value rounded
	down to the nearest integer if its fractional component is not 0.
slots.ceil:
Returns the a number with the receiver's value rounded up to
	the nearest integer if its fractional component is greater than 0.
slots.&(aNumber): Returns a new number with the bitwise AND of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.clip(aNumber1, aNumber2):
Returns self if the receiver is between aNumber1 and aNumber2.
	Returns aNumber1 if it is less than aNumber1. Returns aNumber2 if it is greater than aNumber2.
slots.bitwiseOr(aNumber): Returns a new number with the bitwise AND of the receiver and aNumber.
slots.unsignedShortMax: Returns the minimum unsigned int value.
slots.pow(aNumber): Returns the value of the receiver to the aNumber power.

Number.description: A container for a double (a 64bit floating point number on most platforms).

slots.create:
Create the directory if it doesn't exist. 
	Returns self on success (or if the directory already exists), nil on failure.
slots.fileNames: Returns a list of strings for the names of the files (no subdirectories) in the directory.

slots.filesWithExtension(aString): Returns a list of File objects for the files in the Directory (no directories) with the specified file extension.

Sets the current working directory path.
	Returns true on success or false on error.

slots.currentWorkingDirectory: Returns the current working directory path.
slots.parentDirectory: Returns the parent directory object or nil if there is no parent directory.

Returns a list object containing File and Directory objects
	for the files and directories of the receiver's path.

slots.folderNamedCreateIfAbsent(name): Deprecated. Returns a new Directory object in the directory with the specified name.

Returns a File or Directory object matching the name specified

Directory.credits: Cygwin code by Mike Austin. WIN32 code by Daniel Vollmer.

slots.create: Creates an empty file at the file's path. Returns self on success, nil on failure.

Sets the file path of the receiver to pathString.
	The default path is an empty string. Returns self.

Reads the next line of the file and returns it as a
	string without the return character. Returns Nil if the 
	end of the file has been reached.
slots.thisSourceFile: Returns a File representing the system file in which this Io code exists.
slots.setContents(aSeq): Replaces the contents for the file with aSeq. Returns self.

slots.mode: Returns the open mode of the file(either read, update or append).
slots.isUserExecutable: Returns true if the receiver is user group executable, false otherwise.
slots.foreachLine(optionalLineNumber, line, me:
For each line, set index to the line number of the line and line and execute aMessage. Example usage: 
	
aFile foreachLine(i, v, writeln("Line ", i, ": ", v))
aFile foreach(v, writeln("Line: ", v))

File.description:
Encapsulates file i/o. Here's an example of opening a file, and reversing its lines: 
	
file = File clone openForUpdating("/tmp/test")
lines = file readLines reverse
file rewind
lines foreach(i, line, file write(line, "\n"))
file close
File.credits: Initial version contributed by Miles Egan.

slots.debuggerCoroutine: Returns the coroutine used for the debugger.
slots.vmWillSendMessage: Override this method to implement your own debugging mechanisms. Default behavior is to print every message sent.
slots.description: To start debugging a coroutine, call Coroutine currentCoroutine setMessageDebugging(true) Then each message sent within that coroutine will cause the Debugger vmWillSendMessage slot to be activated and the Debugger slots: messageCoroutine, messageSelf, messageLocals, and message will be set with the values related to the current message send. You can override vmWillSendMessage to implement your own debugging mechanisms.

WeakLink.description:
A WeakLink is a primitive that can hold a reference to 
	an object without preventing the garbage collector from 
	collecting it. The link reference is set with the setLink() method. 
	After the garbage collector collects an object, it informs any 
	(uncollected) WeakLink objects whose link value pointed to that 
	object by calling their "collectedLink" method.

Exception.description:
The Exception proto is used for raising exceptions and instances are used to hold rexception related info.

Raise

An exception can be raised by calling raise() on an exception proto. Exception raise("generic foo exception")

Try and Catch

To catch an exception, the try() method of the Object proto is used. try() will catch any exceptions that occur within it and return the caught exception or nil if no exception is caught. 

e := try()
To catch a particular exception, the Exception catch() method can be used. Example: 
e := try(
    // ...
) 

e catch(Exception,
    writeln(e coroutine backtraceString)
)
The first argument to catch indicates which types of exceptions will be caught. catch() returns the exception if it doesn't match and nil if it does.

Pass

To re-raise an exception caught by try(), use the pass method. This is useful to pass the exception up to the next outer exception handler, usually after all catches failed to match the type of the current exception: 

e := try(
    // ...
) 

e catch(Error,
    // ...
) catch(Exception,
    // ...
) pass

Custom Exceptions

Custom exception types can be implemented by simply cloning an existing Exception type: 

MyErrorType := Error clone

CFunction.description:
A container for a pointer to a C function binding. 
CFunction's can only be defined from the C side and act 
like blocks in that when placed in a slot, are called when the 
slot is activated. The for, if, while and clone methods of the Lobby 
are examples of CFunctions. CFunctions are useful for implementing 
methods that require the speed of C or binding to a C library.

Sets the terminal to curses mode.

Curses.description:
Curses allows writing and reading at arbitrary positions on the terminal. You have to call init to set the terminal to curses mode and end to end curses mode. The terminal is not updated until refresh is called. It is a bad idea to use the standard io's read and write methods when the terminal is in curses mode. The Curses primitive was written by Edwin Zacharias.

Here's an example that prints Hello at column 5 and row 7; 

Curses init
Curses move(5, 7) print(\"Hello\")
Curses refresh
Curses end
Curses.credits: Original version by Edwin Zacharias. getCh method by Scott Dunlop.

slots.priorityMap:
Contains key/value pairs for logging priorities for use when calling the log() method. These include:

  • LOG_EMERG
  • LOG_ALERT
  • LOG_CRIT
  • LOG_ERR
  • LOG_WARNING
  • LOG_NOTICE
  • LOG_INFO
  • LOG_DEBUG
slots.mask(optionalMask):
If optionalMask is specified, optionalMask is a list which contains 
	any one or more values stored in the maskMap hash that will be OR'd 
	together, to provide the proper mask. Returns the logging mask (as a List).
slots.priority(optionalPriority):
If optionalPriority is specified, sets the value, and returns it. 
	If no value is specified, will return the previously stored value if 
	one has been set previously.
slots.log:
Writes the supplied data to the log. Requires 2 arguments:

  • Logging Priority
  • Message to log
slots.optionsMap:
A map containing key/value pairs holding all available options. These include:

  • LOG_PID
  • LOG_CONS
  • LOG_ODELAY
  • LOG_NDELAY
  • LOG_NOWAIT
  • LOG_PERROR
slots.options(optionalOptions):
If optionalOptions is specified, it should represent a list of the logging 
	options you can find in the optionsMap slot. All the values in the supplied 
	aList will be OR'd together when you call the open or reopen slots. 
	Returns the list of options if optionalFacility is omitted.
slots.close: Closes a log that has previously been opened for writing.
slots.facility(optionalFacility):
Specifies the logging facility, which can be one of any of the values 
	found in the facilityMap map. If optionalFacility is omitted, returns 
	the currently set facility.
slots.facilityMap:
Contains the following keys, which represent numbers that can be used when opening a log:

  • LOG_KERN
  • LOG_USER
  • LOG_MAIL
  • LOG_DAEMON
  • LOG_AUTH
  • LOG_SYSLOG
  • LOG_LPR
  • LOG_NEWS
  • LOG_UUCP
  • LOG_CRON
  • LOG_AUTHPRIV
  • LOG_FTP
  • LOG_RESERVED0
  • LOG_RESERVED1
  • LOG_RESERVED2
  • LOG_RESERVED3
  • LOG_LOCAL0
  • LOG_LOCAL1
  • LOG_LOCAL2
  • LOG_LOCAL3
  • LOG_LOCAL4
  • LOG_LOCAL5
  • LOG_LOCAL6
  • LOG_LOCAL7
slots.reopen(aFacility, someOptions, optionalI:
Reopens an already open log session. This is useful if you wish to 
	change the facility you are logging to, the options you are logging 
	with, or the identity of the session. Takes the same options as the open slot.
slots.isOpen: Returns self if the log is opened for writing. Otherwise, returns Nil.
slots.maskMap:
Contains keys/value pairs which represent numbers that specify the logging mask. These values may be any one (or more) of the following:

  • LOG_PRIMASK
  • LOG_FACMASK
slots.identity(optionalIdentity): If optionalIdentity is specified, provides an identity for all of the messages you will be sending to the syslog daemon. Returns the identity.
slots.open(aPriority, someOptions, optionalIde:
Opens the syslog for writing. optionalIdentity need not be entered 
	and will default to the name of the distribution of Io you are running 
	or if you have embedded Io into your application and set 
	Lobby distribution = "foo", it will be set to "foo".

Syslog.description:
Provides access to a Unix system's system logger. 

logger = Syslog clone do(
	identity("SyslogTest")
	facility(facilityMap at("LOG_USER"))
	options(List append(optionsMap at("LOG_PID"), optionsMap at("LOG_CONS")))
	priority(priorityMap at("LOG_INFO"))
	open(facility, options)
	mask(List append(maskMap at("LOG_PRIMASK")))
	log(priority, "*** Merely a test ***")
	close
)

Note: This is partially tested. Please let me know of any problems you happen to stumble across, or if it could be better. --Jeremy Tregunna
